title: Energy transition needs 'staged' approach: AEMO
text:
"We should be enabling new generation not dissuading it," she said. "If we are continually constraining wind and solar generators this is a disincentive for investment, and this is investment that is not only necessary to ensure reliable power but can also create much-needed jobs and activity in regional areas of the country."

AEMO said that "more active management" will also be essential of the growing swell of rooftop solar panels to keep the power system secure, and pointed to the greater level of centralised control of distributed energy systems in some other countries.

The unprecedented speed of Australia's adoption of renewable energy has caused significant disruptions to the market, including the need for AEMO to intervene on a near-daily basis to keep the grid stable, bottlenecks in the grid, and increasing instances where rooftop solar generation is curtailed.

At the same time, baseload coal generators that have traditionally provided critical services such as inertia and frequency control are being forced out of the market.

Energy Security Board chair Kerry Schott told The Australian Financial Review National Energy Summit earlier this month that AEMO was having to intervene in the market more often due to risks to system security, including ensuring the grid kept within voltage limits to avoid an "uncontrollable" system and problems with home appliances.

In the paper, released on Tuesday, AEMO suggests Australia could learn from overseas jurisdictions as regards taking control over small distributed energy devices such as rooftop solar panels, and in managing frequency and inertia.

"International power system operators have taken a staged approach to operating power systems with progressively less synchronous generation online," AEMO said. "A similar approach could be considered in Australia."

Some of the suggestions look set to be seized on by proponents of baseload coal generators such as Trevor St Baker, who has repeatedly warned of the risks of the uncontrolled influx of variable wind and solar onto the grid and the decline of dispatchable generation.

AEMO's Renewable Energy Integration Study points to the example of Texas and Ireland where conventional and renewable generators are required to provide frequency response if needed to handle disturbances on the grid, something not required in the National Electricity Market.

Texas, Ireland and Great Britain also have more comprehensive requirements than the NEM on inertia and change-of-frequency.

A spokesman for the Australian Energy Council, which represents electricity suppliers, said that to some extent active management is already happening in Australia, in particular the “system strength constraint” which, in certain conditions, limits the total production of South Australian wind.

“The issues are very complex and some conservatism may be warranted, but in general the Council would prefer the system is constrained only for tangible, known risks," the spokesman said.
description: The energy market operator has suggested lessons could be learned from Ireland, which sometimes limits the penetration of wind and solar power in the grid.
